Graphical abstract The development halogen-free, solvent-free heterogeneous catalysts for CO2 cycloaddition with epoxides remains critical, as conventional homogeneous systems face challenges in product separation and leave halogen residues. This work addresses these limitations by designing a series of halogen-free M/AlOOH catalysts with different types of doped metal M and surface defects, to optimize CO2 cycloaddition with ethylene oxide (EO) by the regulation of acid-base properties. Theoretical and experimental analyses reveal that Lewis acid-base pairs composed of M∙∙∙VH and M∙∙∙VOH could stabilize the ring-opening intermediates (LO/LC) and promote EO ring-opening over M/AlOOH catalysts. Crucially, activated CO2 δ− species mimic halogen’s nucleophilic role in attacking EO, with catalytic activity exhibiting an inverted volcano relationship to the Bader charge of CO2 δ− species, Optimal performance occurs when the CO2 δ− charge within 0.23 ∼ 0.55 e, where enhanced nucleophilicity drives cycloaddition. This study establishes a rational strategy for designing sustainable heterogeneous catalysts that eliminate halogens and solvents while maintaining high activity, offering a blueprint for green catalytic systems in CO2 utilization. Keywords CO2 cycloaddition Ethylene oxide M/AlOOH Halogen-free Defect types Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ethylene carbonate (EC) synthesis by the CO2 cycloaddition with ethylene oxide (EO) has garnered significant interest owing to its 100 % atom economy and thermodynamic feasibility [1,2]. As a critical chemical precursor, EC finds applications in high-purity polyester production and battery electrolytes, where even trace halogen impurities (<0.2 ppm) severely degrade performance—reducing electrolyte conductivity and compromising its utility in flame retardants, optical media, and specialty plastics [2–4]. Industrially, this reaction employs homogeneous catalysts such as polyethylene glycol/KI or quaternary ammonium salt ionic liquids [5,6], however, these systems suffer from halogen retention in products and laborious separation processes, necessitating costly purification steps to achieve the ultralow halogen thresholds required for premium-grade EC. The heterogenization of homogeneous catalysts—achieved by immobilizing active components such as ionic liquids (ILs), organic bases, and metal complexes onto supports like mesoporous silica, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), or polymers—has emerged as a promising strategy to retain high catalytic activity while enabling facile separation for CO2 cycloaddition reactions [7–9]. However, the stability of these systems hinges critically on the strength of interactions between the active components and the support. Weak bonding often leads to gradual leaching of catalytic species during reuse, resulting in significant activity loss [10]. For example, ILs supported on the B-doped mesoporous SiO2 catalyst exhibited a 25 % decline in propylene carbonate yield after four cycles due to component leaching [7]. These limitations underscore the urgent need to develop fully heterogeneous, halogen-free, and solvent-free catalysts that eliminate reliance on immobilized homogeneous species, thereby addressing persistent challenges in product purification, halogen contamination, and long-term stability for sustainable CO2 utilization. Recent advances in heterogeneous catalysts, particularly metal oxides (e.g., Zn-Mg-Al-O and Zn-TiO2), have highlighted their potential for CO2 cycloaddition due to tunable structures, ease of separation, reusability, and cost-effectiveness [11,12]. However, their performance remains heavily reliant on solvents or halogens. For instance, Zn-Mg-Al-O achieved an 88.8 % yield of propylene carbonate with trimethylamine as a solvent, which reduces viscosity and enhances diffusion, but this dropped to 67.0 % without the solvent [11]. Similarly, Zn-TiO2 exhibited a 92.3 % yield with tetrabutylammonium iodide (TBAI) as a halogen additive, compared to a mere 13.7 % without TBAI, as the halogen facilitated nucleophilic epoxide ring-opening [12]. These results underscore a critical limitation: even high-activity metal oxide catalysts require auxiliary solvents or halogens to maintain efficiency, inevitably introducing halogen residues into products. Such dependencies compromise process sustainability, escalate purification costs, and degrade product quality, emphasizing the need for fully halogen- and solvent-free catalytic systems to advance green CO2 utilization. To overcome these limitations, multimetallic oxides featuring tailored Lewis acid-base pairs have emerged as effective catalysts for synergistic activation of epoxides and CO2, enabling halogen- and solvent-free cycloaddition [13–15], for instance, Ce1-xZrxO2 solid solution with tunable acidity/basicity were synthesized via Zr doping, where Ce0.7Zr0.3O2 with optimized with balanced acid-base sites achieved 90 % conversion and 99 % selectivity for CO2-propylene oxide cycloaddition at 150 °C, 5.0 MPa CO2, 3.0 mL DMF, while the conversion and selectivity were decreased to 84 % and 97 % without DMF [13]. MgO had low yield of 47 % for CO2 cycloaddition with epichlorohydrin [14], while the defective Li-MgO catalyst achieved 96.5 % yield for EO cycloaddition at 130°C and 3.0 MPa CO2 without DMF due to the enhanced surface basicity caused by doping small amount of Li, the generated surface oxygen-defects (OV) acted as Lewis base sites to activate CO2, and Mg2+/Li+ acted as Lewis acid sites to activate EO [15]. For Ce0.7Zr0.3O2 and Li-MgO, the carbonates (CO3 2−) from CO2 activated at the base-site O− were considered as the alternative nucleophile to activate epoxides. These studies underscore that strategic doping or defect engineering in metal oxides can optimize surface acidity-basicity synergy, achieving high-performance CO2 cycloaddition under halogen- and solvent-free conditions, thereby addressing prior limitations of additive dependency. Surface acidity and basicity in catalysts can be precisely modulated through defect engineering. For instance, regulating AlOOH surface defect enables the creation of a high-density Lewis acid-base pair (Al3+ unsatur/VOH), where hydroxyl defect (VOH) defects localize single electrons and reduce Al coordination, thereby weakening Lewis acidity. Conversely, simultaneous H and OH defects enhance Lewis acidity at the adjacent Al3+ sites by leaving orbitals unoccupied and localizing electron pairs on surface oxygen atoms (VH) [16]. Beyond defect type, the distance of acid-base pairs critically governs catalytic behavior. The ZnSn(OH)6 catalyst prepared through morphology control obtained the (111) and (100) surfaces with the acid-base site distance of 0.207 and 0.488 nm, the (111) surface with shorter acid-base distances exhibit stronger CO2 activation ability [17]. Lewis acid sites, including transition metals (Zn, Fe, Co, Ni, etc) and hydrogen bond donor (HBD) groups (−OH, −COOH, −NH2), play a pivotal role in the adsorption and activation of epoxides, driving their ring-opening during CO2 cycloaddition [18]. For example, PENDI catalysts prepared via condensation of 2, 4-pentanedione, and diamine achieved 80 % yield in CO2-epichlorohydrin cycloaddition at 120 °C and 0.7 MPa, where synergistic activation by −OH and −NH groups facilitated epoxide ring-opening [19]. Similarly, SBA-15 ULP silica enhanced NBu4Br’s reactivity through surface Si −OH groups, which acted as weak acidic sites to polarize epoxides via hydrogen bonding [20]. SnO2 demonstrated improved performance with 0.5 mol% TBAI due to cooperative effects between surface hydroxyl groups and Sn2+ Lewis acid sites, enabling efficient epoxide activation [21]. AlOOH-catalyzed epichlorohydrin cycloaddition achieved a CO2 conversion rate increase from 58 % to 99 % with minimal DMF addition, the calculations confirmed that epoxides adsorbed at the surface OH site spontaneously open the ring to facilitate CO2 insertion [22]. Doping a secondary metal into AlOOH significantly enhances its catalytic activity by modulating surface acidity and basicity, as the doped metal disperses uniformly on the AlOOH, altering its local coordination environment [23]. For instance, Co-doped AlOOH increased electronic density at the Fermi level and charge transfer to improve OER activity [24], suggesting similar potential for CO2 cycloaddition when combining metal active centers with abundant surface −OH groups. These findings indicate that adjusting surface defects and metal dopants can fine-tune surface acid-base properties of AlOOH to optimize catalytic performance in CO2 cycloaddition. However, the underlying mechanism of the function of surface defects and doped metal for AlOOH catalysts in affecting catalytic performance of CO2 cycloaddition reaction remains poorly understood. Key challenges persist in strategically constructing Lewis acid-base pairs with appropriate strength and distance. This study aims to engineer AlOOH-based catalysts by modulating surface defect types (e.g., hydroxyl or hydrogen vacancies) and metal dopants (M = transition metals) to construct a series of Lewis acid-base pairs for promoting CO2 cycloaddition with EO. Based on DFT calculations, the mechanism of EO ring-opening and the performance of CO2 cycloaddition under the halogen-free and solvent-free conditions were investigated over M/AlOOH catalysts, aiming at revealing the role of Lewis acid-base properties in regulating the catalytic performance of CO2 cycloaddition with EO. The results are expected to provide atomistic insights into sustainable catalyst design, advancing strategies for efficient CO2 utilization through defect and doping engineering. 2 Computational details 2.1 Calculation methods DFT calculations are carried out within the DMol3 module in Materials Studio 8.0 software by using the Generalized-Gradient Approximation with Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (GGA-PBE) to describe electron exchange–correlation [25–28]. The detailed calculation details are shown in the Supplementary Material. 2.2 Surface models for AlOOH and M/AlOOH catalysts The AlOOH bulk exhibits an orthorhombic symmetry with the Cmc21 space group [29]. Meanwhile, previous studies [30,31] have obtained the phase diagram of AlOOH by Materials Project databases (MP), the formation energies were calculated by the r2SCAN metaGGA functional, and the formation energy for γ-AlOOH used in this work was −2.643 eV/atom, which was higher than the energy hull about 0.007 eV/atom in the stable state, indicating that the γ-AlOOH phase existed in the form of the metastable state. See Fig. 1 a, the Al3+ ions in the AlOOH lie in the distorted and edge-sharing octahedral arrays of four oxygen ions and two hydroxyl groups, the cohesion of the stacked in the y-direction is ensured by hydrogen bonds between hydroxyl groups belonging to two consecutive layers and forming a zig-zag chain along the Z-direction [32,33]. The surface energies for three preferentially exposed surfaces of AlOOH are (010)<(100)<(001), correspondingly, the exposed surface area is (010)>(100)>(001) [25]. Thus, AlOOH(010) is chosen to model the AlOOH catalyst. AlOOH(010) is modeled using a p(3 × 4) supercell with two stacked layers, and the successive slabs are separated by a 15 Å vacuum region to avoid periodic interactions, see Fig. 1b. Generally, the perfect AlOOH catalyst can be synthesized by solvent-thermal method and then treated by defect engineering to obtain the defective AlOOH [24]. Two defect types including surface H and OH vacancies over AlOOH catalysts can be obtained by adjusting the mole ratio of urea and Al(NO3)3·9H2O [16]. Moreover, seven types of metals (Ni, Cu, Zn, Mg, Fe, Co, Pt) were introduced into AlOOH to change the electronic environment of Lewis acid and base sites. The metal-doped perfect AlOOH(010) is named as M/AlOOH-pm0, as shown in Fig. 1c. To clarify the effect of defect types, three types of defective surfaces are considered, in which M/AlOOH-dm1 is constructed by removing an OH group and a H atom from M/AlOOH-pm0 surface to form one OH vacancy (VOH) and one H vacancy (VH), M/AlOOH-dm2 is constructed by removing a OH group from M/AlOOH-pm0 surface to form one VOH, M/AlOOH-dm3 is constructed by removing two surface OH to form two VOH. The formation energy of defects over M/AlOOH-dm catalysts was calculated (Fig. S1), the formation energy of defect follows the order of M/AlOOH-dm1 > M/AlOOH-dm3 > M/AlOOH-dm2, namely, the formation of one VH and one VOH over M/AlOOH-dm catalysts was more difficult compared to the formation of one VOH or two VOH. Meanwhile, the formation energy of defects is Zn > Mg > Cu > Pt > Ni > Fe > Co over M/AlOOH-dm1, that was Co > Fe > Ni > Cu > Pt > Zn > Mg over M/AlOOH-dm2 and Fe > Mg > Co > Zn > Ni > Pt > Cu over M/AlOOH-dm3. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Adsorption and co-adsorption behaviors of CO2 and EO species Fig. 2 and S2 present the stable adsorption configurations of CO2 and EO over M/AlOOH catalysts, the adsorption energies and the geometric parameters are listed in Table S1, which are described in the Supplementary Material. Taking the Fe/AlOOH as an example (Fig. 2 a,b), both CO2 and EO interact with surface OH to form hydrogen bond over Fe/AlOOH-pm0. The VH or VOH and its adjacent metal cations respectively acted as Lewis base and acid sites over Fe/AlOOH-dm1, Fe/AlOOH-dm2, and Fe/AlOOH-dm3, forming Lewis acid-base pairs that synergistically activate CO2, while EO adsorbed at the VOH site. Thus, the physically adsorbed linear state CO2 transforms into a chemically adsorbed bent state CO2 δ− after the introduction of defects. The adsorption behaviors of CO2 and EO species are similar on the other M/AlOOH catalysts. See Fig. 2c, CO2 adsorption energy for the most stable adsorption configuration over Mg, Co, and Fe-doped surfaces is dm1 > dm3 > dm2 > pm0, those on the dm1 is higher than dm2, dm3, pm0 over Ni, Cu, Zn, and Pt-doped surfaces. Compared with M/AlOOH-pm0, CO2 adsorption energy is significantly enhanced over M/AlOOH-dm surfaces, and the physically adsorbed linear state CO2 transforms into a chemically adsorbed bent state CO2 δ−. EO adsorption energy of the most stable adsorption configuration over Cu, Zn, and Mg-doped surfaces is dm1 > dm2 > dm3 > pm0, that is dm1 > dm3 > dm2 > pm0 over Ni, Co, and Fe-doped surfaces; meanwhile, the adsorption of EO over Pt/AlOOH-dm1 and Pt/AlOOH-dm2 is weaker than that over Pt/AlOOH-pm0 and Pt/AlOOH-dm3 (−51.3, −56.9 vs. −72.3, −67.8 kJ∙mol−1). Thus, the types of surface defect and doped metal can change the adsorption energy of CO2 and EO, as well as stabilize CO2 δ− species. Based on the results of CO2 and EO adsorption, as shown in Fig. S3, two co-adsorbed configurations of CO2 and EO are considered, one is CO2 combined with surface exposed O at the VH site to form CO2 δ− species, the other is CO2 linearly adsorbed on the surface OH, and EO coordinated with metal cations near to VOH site. 3.2 Effect of surface defect and doped metal types on the adsorption of LO and LC The ring-opening intermediates of EO and EC, alkoxide (LO) and linear carbonate (LC), are crucial for the steps of EO ring-opening, CO2 insertion, and ring-closure of LC, leading to different reaction pathways of CO2 cycloaddition. Thus, the adsorption behavior of LO and LC intermediates was further investigated. LO adsorption over M/AlOOH-pm0, the optimized structure shows that LO ring-closure to generate EO is a barrier-less process. Over M/AlOOH-dm1 and M/AlOOH-dm3 (Fig. S4a), LO can be stabilized by the binding of the C-end with surface O atom and that of O-end with doped metal cations. For M/AlOOH-dm2 (Fig. S5a), LO stably exists on the Co and Fe-doped surfaces through O-end adsorbed at the VOH site, while its ring-closure is a barrier-less process to form EO over Ni, Cu, Zn, Mg, and Pt-doped surfaces. LC adsorption over M/AlOOH-pm0, the optimized structure shows that LC ring-closure to generate EC is a barrier-less process (Fig. S4b). Over M/AlOOH-dm1 and M/AlOOH-dm3, LC tends to adsorb at the VH or VOH site and bind with doped metal cations via O-end. On the Ni, Cu, Co, Fe, and Pt-doped M/AlOOH-dm2 (Fig. S5b), LC stably adsorbed at the VOH site via O atom, while its ring-closing to form EC is barrier-less over Zn and Mg-doped surfaces. The above results show that surface OH over M/AlOOH-pm0 cannot stabilize the ring-opening intermediate (LO) of EO, as a result, the ring-closure of LO is barrier-less. Meanwhile, previous studies showed that the surface OH of M/AlOOH hardly worked on EO activation compared with the OH in the Silanol, PhOH, and so on [20,21]. Over M/AlOOH-dm1 and M/AlOOH-dm3, the Lewis acid-base sites composed of M∙∙∙VH and M∙∙∙VOH are beneficial for stabilizing the ring-opening intermediates LO and LC. Meanwhile, LO can stably exist on the Co/AlOOH-dm2 and Fe/AlOOH-dm2, while the ring-closure of LO is barrier-less on the other M/AlOOH-dm2 surfaces. LC can stably exist on the Co, Fe, Ni, Cu, and Pt-doped M/AlOOH-dm2, while its ring-closure is barrier-less over Zn and Mg-doped M/AlOOH-dm2. Thus, the types of surface defect and doped metal in the M/AlOOH catalysts obviously affect the stability of ring-opening intermediates LO and LC, as a result, CO2 cycloaddition with EO was carried out by different reaction pathways. 3.3 Proposed halogen-free CO2 cycloaddition pathway over M/AlOOH catalyst Generally, CO2 cycloaddition reactions followed the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (LH) or Eley-Rideal (ER) mechanism, for instance, the cycloaddition of CO2 with styrene oxide (SO) over SiO2-supported pyridine catalysts followed the ER mechanism [34], that was initiated with the preferential adsorption of SO, while CO2 was present in the gas phase, then I− nucleophilically attacked on the SO to open the ring, and further CO2 insertion and ring-closure reactions to produce styrene carbonate. NiXero catalyst with both Lewis acid and base sites catalyzed CO2 cycloaddition with SO via the ER mechanism [35]. Mg-Al mixed oxides catalyzed CO2 cycloaddition reaction via the LH mechanism, that was CO2 activated at the base site to form carbonate species while the epoxide adsorbed at the adjacent acid site, and then the carbonate species nucleophilically attacked the epoxide to open its ring, and the product cyclic carbonate was generated by ring-closure via oxoanion intermediate [36]. Rasal et al. [15] further verified that CO2 cycloaddition reaction over Li-MgO catalysts also followed the LH mechanism. Zhu et al. [37] reported a B r CN/SBA-15 catalyst, DFT calculations showed that CO2 and SO species were activated at the base site –NH group and acid site −B(OH)2 by forming a hydrogen bond, respectively; then, the activated state CO2 cycloaddition with SO to produce SC followed the LH mechanism. Thus, the reaction mechanism of CO2 cycloaddition strongly depends on the catalyst type, CO2 existed in the gas-phase to follow the ER mechanism and in the adsorbed state to follow the LH mechanism. Thus, both the ER and LH mechanisms of CO2 cycloaddition are considered. As shown in Fig. 3 , the ER mechanism assumed that EO adsorbed at the active sites and CO2 was in the gas phase, then the adsorbed state EO* takes place ring-opening to generate LO*, followed by CO2 insertion into LO* to generate EC* (Path 1), or followed by CO2 insertion into LO* to generate LC*, and then the ring-closure of LC* to generate EC* (Path 2). Meanwhile, the ring-opening of adsorbed state EO* with the assistance of gas-phase CO2 is considered, starting from the LO* intermediate of EO* ring-opening, Path 3 is through CO2 insertion into LO* intermediate to produce EC*, Path 4 is through CO2 insertion into LO* intermediate to generate LC*, followed by the ring-closure of LC* to produce EC*. “ER mechanism with the activated state of EO” Path 1: EO*→LO*→CO2 + LO*→EC* Path 2: EO*→LO*→CO2 + LO*→LC*→EC* Path 3: CO2 + EO*→CO2 + LO*→EC* Path 4: CO2 + EO*→CO2 + LO*→LC*→EC* LH mechanism assumed that both CO2 and EO adsorbed at the active sites to form the adsorbed states CO2* and EO*, and then the CO2* species activated EO* to open the ring and catalyze subsequent CO2 cycloaddition reaction. So, EC can be formed by four paths, Path 1 follows the one-step reaction of CO2*+EO*→EC*, Path 2 is through CO2* insertion into EO* to form the ring-opening intermediate LC*, and then the ring-closure of LC* to form EC*. Otherwise, CO2* firstly nucleophilic attacks the ring of EO* to form CO2* and LO*, then, CO2* inserts into LO* to directly obtain the product EC* in Path 3, while EC also can be formed by the insertion of CO2* into LO* to form LC* and followed by the ring-closure of LC* to form EC* in Path 4. “LH mechanism with the activated state of CO2 and EO” Path 1: CO2*+EO*→EC* Path 2: CO2*+EO*→LC*→EC* Path 3: CO2*+EO*→CO2*+LO*→EC* Path 4: CO2*+EO*→CO2*+LO*→LC*→EC* 3.4 Catalytic activity of CO2 cycloaddition reaction over M/AlOOH catalysts 3.4.1 Effect of surface defect and doped metal types on EO ring-opening Previous theoretical studies showed that epoxide ring-opening was a key step in CO2 cycloaddition [38,39]. The widely accepted mechanism for epoxide ring-opening in the homogeneous catalytic systems with the halogen was that the Lewis acid metal or hydrogen bond donor group (HBD) combined with halogen anions synergistically activated EO ring-opening [40,41]. However, in the halogen-free heterogonous systems, CO2 is activated by the base-site O− to form carbonates (CO3 2−) on the metal oxides or with N-containing groups to form carbamate (N-CO2) on the carbon nitride, both CO3 2− and N-CO2 species were considered as the alternative to activate EO [36,42]. Surface OH promoted the ring-opening of epichlorohydrin with barrier-less over α-AlOOH catalysts [22]. Thus, both the active species (CO3 2−, N-CO2) and surface active sites are hopeful to activate EO, leading to its ring-opening. Based on the above analysis, the catalysts M/AlOOH-dm1, Co/AlOOH-dm2, Fe/AlOOH-dm2, and M/AlOOH-dm3 can effectively stabilize LO species and undergo EO ring-opening and CO2 insertion reactions, and thus the mechanism of EO ring-opening is investigated. Three mechanisms are considered to reveal the role of CO2 adsorption state in EO ring-opening, including the linear state CO2-assisted EO ring-opening (L-CO2), the bent state CO2-assisted EO ring-opening (B-CO2) and the direct EO ring-opening (N-CO2), as shown in Figs. S6–S8 and Table S2. As shown in Fig. 4 , the activation energies of EO ring-opening assisted by Linear-CO2 and Non-CO2 over Cu/AlOOH-dm1 are close (117.8 and 120.1 kJ∙mol−1), while Non-CO2 is kinetically favorable than Linear-CO2 and Bent-CO2 on the other catalysts, indicating that Lewis acid-base pairs consisted of M∙∙∙VH and M∙∙∙VOH facilitate EO ring-opening, which is the initial step in the ER mechanism, as well as Paths 3 and 4 in the LH mechanism, thus, the kinetically unfavorable EO ring-opening through L-CO2 and B-CO2 are not considered. Similarly, over an organocatalyst with Frustrated Lewis Pairs (FLPs), the intramolecular infractions acted as Lewis acid sites to coordinate with the O-end of epoxide, and then the intramolecular phosphine acts as a Lewis base site to nucleophilic attack the C-end of epoxide, leading to epoxide ring-opening [43]. Thus, a new mechanism of EO ring-opening that does not require halogens and is independent of CO2 adsorption state was proposed, namely, a suitable Lewis acid-base pair easily enables the ring-opening of EO adsorbed at the VOH site with a low barrier. 3.4.2 Influence of doped metal and defect types on CO2 cycloaddition mechanism and the activity Since the ring-opening intermediates LO* and LC* cannot be stabilized over M/AlOOH-pm0 catalysts, CO2 cycloaddition is carried out only via the one-step path of CO2*+EO*→EC*. As shown in Fig. 5 and Table S3, CO2 cycloaddition is favored thermodynamically with the reaction free energies of −58.8 ∼ -26.0 kJ∙mol−1, and the overall activation free energy (kJ∙mol−1) is Fe (179.8) < Ni (206.0) < Pt (213.3) < Co (256.4) < Cu (258.2) < Zn (263.5) < Mg (281.3), indicating that the Fe/AlOOH-pm0 catalyst presents the highest catalytic activity. Over M/AlOOH-dm1, Co/AlOOH-dm2, Fe/AlOOH-dm2, and M/AlOOH-dm3, the direct ring-opening of EO is kinetically more favorable than EO ring-opening assisted by the linear or bent state CO2, thus, CO2 + EO*→CO2 + LO* in Paths 3 and 4 via ER mechanism and CO2*+EO*→CO2*+LO* in Paths 3 and 4 via LH mechanism are excluded, as a result, the reaction pathways are further simplified to Paths 1 and 2 via LH mechanism, as well as Paths 1 and 2 via ER mechanism. Over Ni, Cu, Zn, Mg, and Pt-doped M/AlOOH-dm2, only Paths 1 and 2 via LH mechanism are considered since the ring-opening intermediate LO cannot stably exist on the surface, other paths involved in LO intermediate are excluded. Over Fe/AlOOH-dm1 (Fig. 6 a), the overall activation free energies of CO2 cycloaddition via Paths 1 and 2 in the ER mechanism are 134.1 and 50.7 kJ∙mol−1, respectively, those are 116.7 and 83.8 kJ∙mol−1 for Paths 1 and 2 in the LH mechanism, thus, EC is dominantly produced by the Path 2 of EO*→LO*→CO2 + LO*→LC*→EC* via the ER mechanism. Over Fe/AlOOH-dm2 (Fig. 6b), Path 1 in the ER mechanism is kinetically favorable than Path 2 in the ER mechanism, as well as Paths 1 and 2 in the LH mechanism (87.6 vs. 160.7, 383.8, 154.8 kJ∙mol−1), namely, EC is mainly formed by the path of EO*→LO*→CO2 + LO*→EC* via the ER mechanism. Over Fe/AlOOH-dm3 (Fig. 6c), Path 2 in the ER mechanism is dominant, which is kinetically more favorable than Path 1 in the ER mechanism, as well as Paths 1 and 2 in the LH mechanism (12.9 vs. 201.9, 223.1, 164.2 kJ∙mol−1). CO2 cycloaddition follows the ER mechanism over Fe/AlOOH-dmx with the activity (kJ∙mol−1) of Fe/AlOOH-dm3 (12.9, Path 2) > Fe/AlOOH-dm1 (50.7, Path 2) > Fe/AlOOH-dm2 (87.6, Path 1). For Ni/AlOOH-dm (Fig. S9), CO2 cycloaddition dominantly goes through Path 1 in the LH mechanism over Ni/AlOOH-dm1, Path 2 over Ni/AlOOH-dm2, while it is Path 2 in the ER mechanism over Ni/AlOOH-dm3; CO2 cycloaddition activity is Ni/AlOOH-dm3 (42.8) > Ni/AlOOH-dm2 (118.5) > Ni/AlOOH-dm1 (124.8). For Cu/AlOOH-dm (Fig. S10), Path 2 in the LH mechanism is dominant over Cu/AlOOH-dm1 and Cu/AlOOH-dm3, while it is Path 1 in the LH mechanism over Cu/AlOOH-dm2, CO2 cycloaddition activity is Cu/AlOOH-dm3 (119.6) > Cu/AlOOH-dm1 (160.3) > Cu/AlOOH-dm2 (217.6). For Zn/AlOOH-dm (Fig. S11), the Zn/AlOOH-dm1 and Zn/AlOOH-dm3 catalysts prefer Path 2 via the ER mechanism; that is Path 1 via the LH mechanism over Zn/AlOOH-dm2; CO2 cycloaddition activity is Zn/AlOOH-dm3 (59.5) > Zn/AlOOH-dm1 (132.4) > Zn/AlOOH-dm2 (293.2). For Mg/AlOOH-dm (Fig. S12), the preferred path is Path 2 via the ER mechanism over Mg/AlOOH-dm1, Path 1 via the LH mechanism (CO2*+EO*→EC*) over Mg/AlOOH-dm2 and Path 1 via the ER mechanism over Mg/AlOOH-dm3; CO2 cycloaddition activity is Mg/AlOOH-dm3 (52.4) > Mg/AlOOH-dm1 (192.9) > Mg/AlOOH-dm2 (273.2). For Co/AlOOH-dm (Fig. S13), CO2 cycloaddition follows the ER mechanism, and CO2 cycloaddition activity is Co/AlOOH-dm2 (79.1, Path 2) > Co/AlOOH-dm1 (77.8, Path 1) > Co/AlOOH-dm3 (192.2, Path 2). For Pt/AlOOH-dm (Fig. S14), CO2 cycloaddition activity and the preferred path are Pt/AlOOH-dm3 (59.6, Path 2 via ER) > Pt/AlOOH-dm1 (134.0, Path 2 via ER) > Pt/AlOOH-dm2 (167.6, Path 1 via LH). The overall activation free energy of the most favorable path for CO2 cycloaddition over M/AlOOH-dm catalysts is used to evaluate CO2 cycloaddition activity, as shown in Fig. 7 . For the catalysts with the same defect type but different doped metals, over M/AlOOH-dm1, CO2 cycloaddition activity (kJ∙mol−1) is Fe (50.7) > Co (77.8) > Pt (119.7) > Ni (124.8) > Zn (132.4) > Cu (160.3) > Mg (192.9), those are Co (79.1) > Fe (87.6) > Ni (118.5) > Pt (167.6) > Cu (217.6) > Mg (273.2) > Zn (293.2) over M/AlOOH-dm2, and it is Fe (12.9) > Ni (42.8) > Mg (52.4) > Zn (59.5) > Pt (59.6) > Cu (119.6) > Co (192.2) over M/AlOOH-dm3. Among each type of M/AlOOH-dmx catalysts, three catalysts with specific doped metal, Fe/AlOOH-dm1, Co/AlOOH-dm2 and Fe/AlOOH-dm3, are screened out to exhibit the highest CO2 cycloaddition activity, moreover, Fe/AlOOH-dm3 presents higher activity than both Fe/AlOOH-dm1 and Co/AlOOH-dm2 catalysts. 3.4.3 CO2 cycloaddition activity based on the rate-determining step Rate-determining step (RDS) was critical for chemical kinetics, which means that the slowest step with the largest activation free energy (G a) should control the total kinetic of a series of processes [44,45]. Table S4 summarizes the rate-determining step (RDS) and its activation free energy of CO2 cycloaddition through the LH-Path 1, LH-Path 2, ER-Path 1 and ER-Path 2 over M/AlOOH-dm catalysts. For 3 types of catalysts via the ER-Path 1, the activation free energy of RDS (kJ∙mol−1) is Co/AlOOH-dm1 (292.5), Fe/AlOOH-dm2 (117.9), Mg/AlOOH-dm3 (258.4). For 10 types of catalysts via the ER-Path 2, that is Zn/AlOOH-dm1 (313.2), Mg/AlOOH-dm1 (362.2), Fe/AlOOH-dm1 (254.0), Pt/AlOOH-dm1 (172.1), Co/AlOOH-dm2 (169.0), Ni/AlOOH-dm3 (210.0), Zn/AlOOH-dm3 (220.7), Co/AlOOH-dm3 (498.8), Fe/AlOOH-dm3 (296.5) and Pt/AlOOH-dm3 (298.6). Thus, the extremely high activation free energy of the RDS is expected to affect the overall reaction rate. Alternatively, applying the RDS as the activity determining criterion, CO2 cycloaddition reaction dominantly follows LH-Path 1 on the 12 types of catalysts Ni/AlOOH-dm1, Cu/AlOOH-dm2, Zn/AlOOH-dm2, Zn/AlOOH-dm3, Mg/AlOOH-dm1, Mg/AlOOH-dm2, Mg/AlOOH-dm3, Fe/AlOOH-dm3, Co/AlOOH-dm1, Pt/AlOOH-dm1, Pt/AlOOH-dm2, and Pt/AlOOH-dm3. However, for CO2 cycloaddition via the dominant LH-Path 2 on the other 9 types of catalysts, the RDS of Ni/AlOOH-dm2 and Fe/AlOOH-dm2 in LH-Path 2 is CO2 + EO → LC; meanwhile, that is LC → EC over 7 types of catalysts Fe/AlOOH-dm1, Cu/AlOOH-dm1, Zn/AlOOH-dm1, Co/AlOOH-dm2, Ni/AlOOH-dm3, Cu/AlOOH-dm3, and Co/AlOOH-dm3. For the catalysts with the same defect type but different doped metal, the activation free energy of RDS (kJ∙mol−1) in the optimal path over M/AlOOH-dm1 is Fe (93.8) < Ni (124.8) < Co (128.7) < Pt (143.6) < Zn (174.3) < Cu (182.3) < Mg (286.8), that over M/AlOOH-dm2 is Fe (66.8) < Ni (118.5) < Pt (167.6) < Co (169.0) < Cu (217.6) < Mg (273.2) < Zn (293.2), and that is Zn (94.0) < Mg (122.8) < Cu (128.4) < Pt (166.7) < Ni (210.0) < Fe (223.1) < Co (365.1) over M/AlOOH-dm3. The RDS in the LH-Path 2 over Fe/AlOOH-dm2 is endothermic, leading to the high overall activation free energy, while CO2 cycloaddition via the ER-Path 1 with the RDS activation free energy of 117.9 kJ∙mol−1 present the lowest overall activation free energy of 87.6 kJ∙mol−1. As shown in Fig. 7, for CO2 cycloaddition reaction, the overall activation free energy of the most favorable path obtained by employing RDS acted as the evaluation criterion, the catalytic activity (kJ∙mol−1) of CO2 cycloaddition over M/AlOOH-dm1 is Fe (83.8) > Ni (124.8) > Co (128.7) > Pt (143.6) > Zn (153.8) > Cu (160.3) > Mg (286.8), that over M/AlOOH-dm2 is Fe (87.6) > Co (108.4) > Ni (118.5) > Pt (167.6) > Cu (217.6) > Mg (273.2) > Zn (293.2), and that over M/AlOOH-dm3 is Zn (94.0) > Ni (112.6) > Cu (119.6) > Mg (122.8) > Pt (166.7) > Co (205.3) > Fe (223.1). Thus, 3 types of catalysts in each type of specific defect are screened out, following the activity order of Fe/AlOOH-dm1 (83.8) > Fe/AlOOH-dm2 (87.6) > Zn/AlOOH-dm3 (94.0). Based on the above results, taking the overall activation free energy of the most favorable path obtained by employing the total reaction and RDS acted as the evaluation criterion into consideration, the Fe/AlOOH-dm1 catalyst is screened out to present the relatively better CO2 cycloaddition activity. Thus, whether the overall activation free energy of the most favorable path obtained by employing the total reaction and RDS acted as the activity evaluation criterion, the screened M/AlOOH catalysts indeed present better catalytic activity for CO2 cycloaddition via the LH mechanism under the halogen-free conditions. 3.4.4 Comparison between M/AlOOH and previously reported catalysts As listed in Table S5, the ZnMgAlO, MgAlO and Ce0.7Zr0.3O2 mixed oxides presented high conversion of epoxide and product selectivity using DMF [11,13], the porous PN-CeO2, Ir-doped Ir1-WO3, and Hf-MOFs with halogen-containing additives TBAB could achieve high CO2 cycloaddition performance [11,46,47]. CaAl-LDH, ZnAl-LDH, and MgFeAl-LDH hydroxides can efficiently catalyze CO2 cycloaddition with the assistance of DMF or TBAB [48–50]. The perfect α-AlOOH catalyzed CO2 cycloaddition with epichlorohydrin presented 99 % conversion using DMF as a solvent, while it decreased to 58 % without DMF [22]. Meanwhile, Ce0.7Zr0.3O2 and Li-MgO could catalyze CO2 cycloaddition with epoxides under the halogen- and solvent-free conditions [13,15], Li-MgO was the most active for CO2 cycloaddition with EO, presenting excellent conversion of 98.9 % and EC yield of 96.5 % at 130 °C, 3.0 MPa CO2, the apparent activation energy in experiment was only 63.1 kJ∙mol−1. Guo et al. [51] calculated CO2 cycloaddition reaction on the single-atom Li loaded MgO(100) and compared it with pure MgO, the results showed that CO2 cycloaddition with EO over MgO has a large activation energy of 278.1 kJ∙mol−1, while it was only 39.8 kJ∙mol−1 over Li-MgO with one-step path of CO2*+EO*→EC*. For the other heterogenous catalysts Cu-MOF, Ir1-WO3, and Mo-doped g-C3N4, the overall activation energies of CO2 cycloaddition reaction were 120.5, 62.7, and 20.5 kJ∙mol−1, respectively, in which epoxide ring-opening was the decisive step [52,53]. For α-AlOOH, epichlorohydrin was firstly adsorbed at the Al ions and then opened the ring with barrier-less under the nucleophilic attack of the O atom, the overall activation energy of CO2 cycloaddition with epichlorohydrin was 136.5 kJ∙mol−1 [22]. Above analysis shows that the high-performance catalysts reported in the previously experimental and theoretical work are all realized in the presence of halogen-containing additives such as polar solvents DMF or TBAB, while the Fe/AlOOH-dm1 (83.8 kJ∙mol−1), Fe/AlOOH-dm2 (87.6 kJ∙mol−1), Zn/AlOOH-dm3 (94.0 kJ∙mol−1) catalysts in our work exhibits the relatively higher activity to catalyze CO2 cycloaddition without the addition of halogens. Although the catalytic performance of the screened catalyst was not verified by the experiments, the feasibility of the screened new catalyst has been indirectly verified by above comparison between the relevant calculation results and previously similar experimental results. Furthermore, based on our results, it is noted that the catalytic performance of CO2 cycloaddition reaction over M/AlOOH catalysts without DMF or halide is expected to be less efficient than the catalysts with DMF or halide as reported in the previous works, while this study provides critical structural insights and theoretical foundations for designing high-efficiency halogen- and solvent-free heterogeneous catalysts in CO2 cycloaddition. Future work will focus on optimizing defect engineering strategies, refining acid-base site cooperativity, and validating catalyst robustness under scalable conditions. These efforts aim to bridge the gap between mechanistic understanding and practical application, ultimately enabling the development of sustainable catalytic systems that eliminate reliance on halogens and solvents while maintaining exceptional activity and stability for CO2 cycloaddition. 3.5 Analysis of acidic-basic properties of catalysts and their effects on reactivity 3.5.1 Doped metals and defect types to affect electronic properties of M/AlOOH To elucidate the effect of surface defects and doped metal types on the electronic properties of M/AlOOH catalysts, both the density of states and Bader charge analysis are carried out. For instance, Detz et al. [54] reported the change of Ru-induced band gap states after the adsorption of single Ru atom and its interaction with MoS2 surface, revealing that the origin of high activity for CO2 reduction to methanol over Ru@MoS2 was from the Ru-Mo-3S moiety. In the case of Fe/AlOOH as an example, as shown in Fig. S15, the O-2p and Al-2p orbitals contribute most of the electronic density of states, while the doped metal Fe-3d contributes less to the overall density of states. Moreover, in comparison with Fe/AlOOH-pm0, the overall electronic states over Fe/AlOOH-dm1 and Fe/AlOOH-dm3 catalysts are closer to the Fermi energy, and thus enhanced the stability of adsorption bonding and effectively promoted EO activation. Fe/AlOOH-dm2 is far from the Fermi energy, resulting in the anti-bonding orbital being filled with electrons, and thus weakens the adsorption capacity of EO, which is not conducive to EO ring-opening. Figs. S16–19 present the local density of states for Al-2p, M−3d or 2p (Ni-, Cu-, Zn-, Co-, Fe-, Pt-3d, Mg-2p), O-2p, H-1s orbitals over M/AlOOH-pm0, M/AlOOH-dm1, M/AlOOH-dm2, and M/AlOOH-dm3 catalysts with different doped metals, in which there are two regions appeared in the left side of Fermi level, the first one (-10 ∼ 0 eV) can be largely contributed to the O-2p, Al-2p, H-1s, M−3d (Mg-2p) states; while small contributions from O-2p, Al-2p, H-1s states could be still observed at the second peaks (-25 ∼ -15 eV). In the right side, the M−3d (Mg-2p) states are strongly hybridized with the O-2p, indicating the formation of the chemical bonds between the doped M and O atoms over M/AlOOH catalysts. Furthermore, over Cu/AlOOH-pm0, Zn/AlOOH-pm0 and Mg/AlOOH-pm0 catalysts, the first peak in the left side crossed the Fermi level, while the introduction defects induced it shift left and an obvious defects state can be observed. Such a defective state could promote the adsorption and activation of CO2 and EO, namely, the defect states of M/AlOOH catalysts contributed to high activity rather than their chemical M−O bonds. Thus, changing the type of doped metal has little effect on the surface electronic state of the catalyst, but the type of defect can cause a shift in the electronic state of defect site, which can obviously affect the adsorption ability of the reactants, and further regulate the catalytic performance. Fig. 8 presents the differential charge density and the corresponding Bader charge transfer of doped metal for the Fe/AlOOH-dm1, Fe/AlOOH-dm2, and Fe/AlOOH-dm3, as well as the M/AlOOH-pm0 (M=Ni, Cu, Zn, Mg, Co, Fe, Pt) catalysts. As shown in Fig. 8a, both the VH and VOH sites enrich the electrons due to the absence of an H atom or OH group, and the electron density of VH is smaller than those of the VOH site over Fe/AlOOH-dm1. Similarly, the VOH site is electron-enriched over Fe/AlOOH-dm2; two VOH sites near the doped Fe are also electron-enriched with a symmetric distribution over Fe/AlOOH-dm3. The same thing about the effect of surface defects on the electronic environment of active sites also occurs on the other M/AlOOH-dm catalysts. Thus, the construction of VH or VOH defects could effectively regulate the electronic environment on the catalyst surface and promote electron enrichment at the defect active sites, which is beneficial for the adsorption and activation of reactants. Bader charges as an important descriptor can characterize the surface acid-base properties of metal oxides, in which the Lewis acid site presents electron deficiency [55]. As shown in Fig. 8b, the doped metal loses electrons to metal ions over M/AlOOH-pm0 catalysts and thus shows the positive valence state, but the abilities to gain or lose electrons markedly depend on metal type, leading to different Bader charge transfer. Bader charges (e) of doped metals is Mg (1.65) > Fe (1.36) > Zn (1.34) > Co (1.27) > Ni (1.24) > Cu (1.21) > Pt (1.09) over M/AlOOH-pm0, that is Mg (1.64) > Fe (1.36) > Zn (1.26) > Co (1.16) > Ni (1.12) > Cu (1.09) > Pt (0.92) over M/AlOOH-dm1, Mg (1.43) > Zn (1.24)≈Fe (1.23) > Cu (1.01)≈Co (1.00) > Ni (0.90) > Pt (0.62) over M/AlOOH-dm2, and Mg (1.19) > Fe (0.71) > Zn (0.66) > Co (0.61)=Ni (0.61) > Cu (0.55) > Pt (0.23) over M/AlOOH-dm3, namely, the type of doped metal affected the strength of surface acid sites. Compared with M/AlOOH-pm0, the electrons enriched at the VH or VOH sites over M/AlOOH-dm prefer to flow into the doped metal, decreasing Bader charge transfer and electron receptivity of M, and then weakens acidity. Thus, the introduction of defects and Al atom replaced by other metals change electronic environment of M/AlOOH catalyst, the acidity strength can be regulated by the types of doped metal and surface defect. Furthermore, the strategy of regulating electronic structure was also used in dense single-atom catalysts to enhance alkene epoxidation [56]. 3.5.2 Relationship of acid-base site strength with EO ring-opening performance As mentioned above, Lewis acid-base pairs composed of M∙∙∙VH and M∙∙∙VOH could stabilize the ring-opening intermediates (LO/LC) and promote EO ring-opening over M/AlOOH. To further clarify the effect of Lewis acid-base properties on EO ring-opening activity, Bader charges of acid (M) and base (VH or VOH) sites over M/AlOOH-dm1, Co/AlOOH-dm2, Fe/AlOOH-dm2 and M/AlOOH-dm3 are calculated. For the acid sites, more negative values mean higher electron receptivity and thus the stronger Lewis acidity. For the base sites, more positive value means stronger Lewis basicity. As shown in Fig. 9 a, the catalysts falling on the left side of the blue dashed line (<−0.8 e) have the stronger acidity, which correlates poorly with EO ring-opening activity. While M/AlOOH-dm3 at the right side (>−0.8 e) shows that the acidity is positively correlated with EO ring-opening activity. As shown in Fig. 9b, Bader charge of the base site show an inverted volcano curve with EO ring-opening activity, with the increasing of Bader charge of base site, EO ring-opening activity firstly increases at the left side (<1.6 e), while it gradually decreases at the right side (>1.6 e). This underscores the activity of EO ring-opening is primarily governed by basicity, not acidity, Fe/AlOOH-dm3 with moderate acidity and basicity achieves peak activity, whereas overly weak or strong basicity diminishes performance. These findings highlight the critical interplay of acid-base synergies in tuning catalytic efficacy, with moderate basicity being pivotal for efficient EO ring-opening. 3.5.3 Determined factor to affect the performance of CO2 cycloaddition reaction This work evaluated 28 types of M/AlOOH catalysts by employing the RDS acted as the activity descriptor to obtain the overall activation free energy of the most favorable path. Among these, the Fe/AlOOH-dm2 catalyst follows the ER mechanism, and EO ring-opening is mainly carried out by Lewis acid-base pairs M∙∙∙VOH, while CO2 cycloaddition mainly goes through the LH mechanism on the other catalysts, in which activated CO2 δ− species is the key to activate EO and increase CO2 cycloaddition activity, and play a key role in the nucleophilic attack of EO to generate EC. This CO2 δ− mediated pathway underscores its dual role in both substrate activation and nucleophilic ring-opening, establishing it as a pivotal intermediate for optimizing halogen- and solvent-free CO2 cycloaddition. As shown in Fig. 10 , CO2 cycloaddition activity exhibits an inverted volcano relationship with the Bader charge of CO2 δ− species (range: −0.06 ∼ 0.93 e). On the left side of curve (−0.06 ∼ 0.4 e), activity increases with rising CO2 δ− charges, peaking at moderate charges (0.23 and 0.55 e), as seen in Fe/AlOOH-dm1 and Fe/AlOOH-dm2 catalysts, which achieve optimal performance. Thus, CO2 cycloaddition activity can be determined by Bader charge of active CO2 δ− species, which can be modulated via surface defect engineering and metal doping over M/AlOOH catalysts. Furthermore, the charge of CO2 δ− species within the range of 0.23 ∼ 0.55 e could enhance CO2 cycloaddition activity. It was also important to reveal the connection between Lewis acid-base properties and catalytic activity since CO2 cycloaddition reaction was the acid-base catalyzed process. Above results showed that CO2 and EO interact with surface OH through hydrogen-bond interaction over M/AlOOH-pm0. Over the defective M/AlOOH-dm catalysts, the surface defects (VH or VOH) acted as Lewis base sites to activate CO2, and the metal adjacent to the defects acted as Lewis acid sites to activate EO. However, DFT results reveal no direct correlation between substrate adsorption energies and activity (Fig. S20), emphasizing that activated CO2 δ− species by Lewis acid-base pairs could be acted as the nucleophilic agent to attack EO, promoting CO2 cycloaddition reaction on the defective M/AlOOH-dm catalysts. These insights establish CO2 δ− charge as a critical activity descriptor and provide actionable guidelines for designing halogen- and solvent-free catalysts through strategic defect and dopant control to optimize acid-base cooperativity. 4 Conclusions This work employed DFT calculations to explore the halogen- and solvent-free CO2 cycloaddition with ethylene oxide (EO) over M/AlOOH catalysts, focusing on rational design of Lewis acid-base site strength through surface defect engineering (VH/VOH) and metal doping (M = Fe, Co, etc.). The results demonstrated that M/AlOOH-dm1, Co/AlOOH-dm2, Fe/AlOOH-dm2 and M/AlOOH-dm3 with Lewis acid-base pairs (M∙∙∙VH and M∙∙∙VOH) effectively facilitate EO ring-opening and stabilize the ring-opening intermediates (LO and LC). By adopting the rate-determining step (RDS) as the activity descriptor, governing overall reaction kinetics. The study revealed an inverted volcano relationship between CO2 cycloaddition activity and the Bader charge of activated CO2 δ− species, both Fe/AlOOH-dm1 and Fe/AlOOH-dm2 catalysts with the moderate charge of CO2 δ− species present higher activity, namely, CO2 cycloaddition activity can be enhanced by adjusting the types of surface defects and doped metals over M/AlOOH catalysts to obtain CO2 δ− species with moderate electronegativity (0.23 ∼ 0.55 e). A breakthrough Fe/AlOOH-dm1 catalyst, engineered with synergistic M∙∙∙VH and M∙∙∙VOH Lewis acid-base pairs, demonstrates exceptional halogen- and solvent-free CO2 cycloaddition activity, rivaling both homogeneous (e.g., ionic liquids) and heterogeneous (e.g., metal oxides with halides) systems reported previously. While current experimental benchmarks for halogen/solvent-free catalysts remain below the performance of additive-assisted systems, this work establishes a critical mechanistic foundation: Bader charge analysis reveals that optimizing CO2 δ− electronegativity (0.23–0.55 e) through defect and dopant engineering enables efficient nucleophilic activation of EO. Though direct parity with halogen- or DMF-enhanced systems is not yet achieved, the Fe/AlOOH-dm1 prototype provides actionable structural insights—specifically, the necessity of balanced acid-base cooperativity and charge-modulated CO2 δ− intermediates—to guide the rational design of next-generation sustainable catalysts. These findings bridge the gap between theoretical catalyst design and practical performance, offering a strategic roadmap to advance halogen- and solvent-free CO2 cycloaddition technologies. coredata.dc:description: The development halogen-free, solvent-free heterogeneous catalysts for CO2 cycloaddition with epoxides remains critical, as conventional homogeneous systems face challenges in product separation and leave halogen residues. This work addresses these limitations by designing a series of halogen-free M/AlOOH catalysts with different types of doped metal M and surface defects, to optimize CO2 cycloaddition with ethylene oxide (EO) by the regulation of acid-base properties. Theoretical and experimental analyses reveal that Lewis acid-base pairs composed of M∙∙∙VH and M∙∙∙VOH could stabilize the ring-opening intermediates (LO/LC) and promote EO ring-opening over M/AlOOH catalysts. Crucially, activated CO2 δ− species mimic halogen’s nucleophilic role in attacking EO, with catalytic activity exhibiting an inverted volcano relationship to the Bader charge of CO2 δ− species, Optimal performance occurs when the CO2 δ− charge within 0.23 ∼ 0.55 e, where enhanced nucleophilicity drives cycloaddition. This study establishes a rational strategy for designing sustainable heterogeneous catalysts that eliminate halogens and solvents while maintaining high activity, offering a blueprint for green catalytic systems in CO2 utilization.
